To everyone talking about how flimsy american doors are: this was an interior door, made for privacy. Not an exterior door, made for security. Exterior doors are several inches of solid wood, and usually have a metal casing around that wood. You would not be able to do this to an exterior door. If wherever you live has interior doors that are heavy duty, then not only is that very inconvenient, but also a giant waste of wood and metal. So congrats on needlessly using natural resources, I guess.

You should find something which can build a sturdy structure going to a wall directly across from the door, if possible. For instance, you could cut a 2x4 board to size to fit in that space. So as long as it cannot wiggle out of place, you've got yourself a feasible barricade. Another thing- if you have hardwood floor, your pile o' stuff will slide more easily. Wooden doors? Try metal. Even our cheap 1970s mobile home has a metal door on it. You could probably rip it out of its hinges, but properly barricaded, you're not going to snap it in half and eventually shove the debris out of your way. In fact, it has TWO doors, a screen door and a metal door in-behind that one. You could probably bust through the glass (at some pretty good risk of injury to yourself) and then you'd have to break both that door frame (or rip it off) and THEN get through that metal door AND the barricade. While you're doing that, I'd be down in the basement grabbing a shotgun and taking up a defensive position, with the lights out (leaving the kitchen lights on). There are too many variables in this myth to call it plausible, and 1 big key feature that is never brought up in movies and means this entire thing is pointless. Even if you have successfully kept the guy out... Now what? You are locked in a room with little to no food or water, and you can't risk taking down the barricade. So you are now trapped. If you were on a ground floor or first level then the window is your only hope, but the guy once he realizes the door is a no go will immediately go to the windows so you are hoping that bracing the door bought you enough time to escape from the room before they got to the window, AND that you are out of eyesight, because if the guy sees you running, well you are in the same predicament as before. That's the thing, this strategy being used is not going to work. You won't escape. HOWEVER Barricading a door is not a bad idea. You aren't trying to stop the guy, but just slow him down enough for yourself to escape. You don't need to stop him, just hinder him. Your only thing is making sure the time the barricade buys you is more than it cost you.

what you need to do if you ever need to do this is stack the furniture in between the door and the opposite wall.  move all the furniture you can between those two points, like they do in the second try, but don't leave any room at all.  cram as much stuff in as possible and shove stuff into any space that you can.  even if it doesn't fully work, you can give yourself enough time to escape from a window or prepare for the attacker.  if there is any room between your first object and door, then you need to put more furniture in the gap.  something flat backed, like a dresser, would work better than a bed since a good deal of headboards are sloped or don't go all the way down, especially in hotels.

Breaking the door down like that would not be possible in Sweden. The doors we have here is mostly NOT made of plywood (thin layers of wood stuck together), but rather one whole solid, thick piece of wood. Trying to break such a door by pure force is pointless without some kind of tool, like an axe, and even then the door would likely take some time to get down.
I learned about this difference personally between a Swedish door and a door on Amerikan TV shows, when the bathroom door broke down (refused to react to handle and so got completely stuck). I tried not only to kick it but also an full out body tackle.
I got more hurt than the door did from when I bounced off from that solid force of a door. And even after that I decided to turn my back to the door, take some support from opposite wall to said door (the bathroom connected to a narrow hallway thankfully) and kicked out. I then continued to kick out for a good 20-ish minutes. The damn door took no damage whatsoever.
In a game I'm pretty certain this door would be put in as that impossible boss that is more of a joke then an serious boss.
In the end I had to sacrifice my library card to pend up the lock. That was fun to explain on the next trip to the library.


Of course this says nothing regarding if or if not you could barricade a door in Sweden with the furniture in a room. The only thing I can be certain about is that if you can lock the door (here in Sweden) than nothing is getting through it for a while (this rule does not ably to guns, bullets go straight through our doors just as they do for everyone else's).

To have any chance of success, you want to brace the door against the opposite wall if you can: Bookshelf covers door, cause that dang thing is too thin, and it helps prevent someone from just pushing in the top quite so easily. Next push the desk the long way against bookshelf (length towards opposite wall from door); chairs and remaining furniture need to go the long way (laid down if need be) to extend the horizontal "brace" until it touches the other wall; preferably along the bottom stud. When someone applies force to the door, the force should get transferred to the opposite wall. If something has a tendency to "pop up", sit on it. If the furniture doesn't quite reach, you can lay or sit with your feet on the opposite wall to help fill in the gap. Keep your feet along the bottom stud, or vertical studs if you can find them - no point in having someone trying to break in push you through the drywall.

One thing they "failed" there is the wall itself. Due to it being a set, they had to put the 2x4 every 12" or so. Houses are 16 or 24". The wall itself appear to be plywood. Houses are drywall. Where I am going with this? Simple, pass throught the wall.

As for those complaining about the hollow core doors, that is almost all interior doors. Unless you are in a very expensive (like millions dollar house) it is almost sure to be that: 1/8" wood, cardboard, 1/8" wood, 1" wood frame all around with a piece of wood for the handle.

Full wood doors, probably wouln't have been much better. They ain't one solid piece of wood, but a few ones glued together. There is also many quality for them, the entry level will be about 1/8" wood full size, multi-pieces core, and another 1/8" wood. This allow to use cheaper wood for the inside, and have the exterior defect free. This is done by basically shaving the tree to get a long sheet, then they remove the defects, and cut the sheets around the defects to get defect free sheets.

Full wood door 100% same/thick, there is basically no tree that is this big, so they will glue several pieces together. Next time you see one, look at it's design, you will most likelly see the two vertical side to be only a few inches wide (like 6-8"), with a top and bottom piece, and most likelly one or more center horisontal pieces. Then they just fill the 'holes' with a piece of wood of a smallish size.

As you can realise, they are stronger yes, but still just a bunch of piece of wood glued together...

And still fastened to the frame by the same short screws... That are easyish to rip off.

If that door was made of solid wood. Tommy would have never broke in. The problem is that when he slams the door into the blockade. It creates a small space where thr objects are now either squished or slightly away from the door. Allowing for more ane more clearance. This is why leaning an object into and under the door handle works so well. The door trying to open causesleverage between the object and the floor- where you are basically pushing against the ground and you ain't winning that. Same problem though
If the object moves...slides.. Etc when he hits the door...it can eventually breakdown. I would have liked to see a better leverage/wedge setup. When they stacked from wall to wall it worked well. But small gaps and fabric differences eventually made it so they werent wedged and he could just push the front objects out of the way without them being wedged and moving together. Making sure the doors clearance to the objects is minimal and the objects are 100% wedged in the opposite direction of the door. Then i dont see the person getting in.
